Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Collaborative Research: GPS observations of post-seismic deformation from the 3 Sep 2016, Mw 5.8, Pawnee, Oklahoma
Award.AbstractNarration:
We propose to use GPS technology in the area of the Pawnee earthquake to measure slow movements of the ground caused by the earthquake that are expected to occur there during the next 1-2 years. One of the causes of these so-called ?post-seismic? movements after natural earthquakes is the readjustment of fluids around the fault to the new crustal stress field generated by the earthquake. The injection of wastewater in Oklahoma from oil production has increased from 5 to 10 times since 2009, and this increased injection rate is thought to have induced a concurrent 450% increase in the number of earthquakes in this state. The Pawnee earthquake is the largest historical event in Oklahoma and, if confirmed that it is induced, among the largest induced earthquakes to date worldwide. The proposed work will provide the first capture of the postseismic deformation field of an earthquake not associated with a seismically active plate boundary such as the existing in California, and if confirmed that it is induced, a human induced earthquake. Analysis of the post-seismic signal will contribute to understanding the role of fluid, and the injection of fluid, in both natural and possibly induced earthquakes, and guide development of strategies to mitigate damage from earthquakes induced by fluid injection.

We propose installing 8 geodetically monumented, Continuous GPS (CGPS) stations to perform post-seismic deformation measurements in the epicentral region of the 3 September 2016, M 5.8, Pawnee, Oklahoma earthquake. In addition to being intraplate, and the largest historical earthquake in Oklahoma, this event also occurred within a region experiencing an exponential increase in seismic activity since the start of 2009 that we think is related to a significant coincident increase in the rate of disposal by injection of wastewater from petroleum production. An earthquake this size should produce a measurable postseismic deformation signal over a period of a few years that can provide important information about the event and the properties and state of the crust and faults in the epicentral region. The CGPS measurements will complement seismic and other geophysical studies of this earthquake by providing data on post-seismic crustal deformation, especially the fluid poroelastic component, caused by the earthquake. Such data will be essential for modeling crustal and fault properties, potentially contribute to improving our understanding the role of fluids in the earthquake process, and reducing seismic hazard from induced earthquakes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project installed and operated 8 continuous GPS (cGPS) stations in the epicentral area of the 2016, M5,8, Pawnee, Okalhoma, earthquake starting soon after the earthqake to record the post-seismic deformation that follows earthquakes. This earthquake was the largest in the history of Oklahoma and part of an induced, 200% increase in earthquake activity in Oklahoma during the previous 7 years.

The project was a collaboration between the University of Oklahoma (OU), the Okalhoma Geological Survey (OGS), and the GPS group at the Center for Earthquake Research and Information (CERI) of the University of Memphis, with equipment support from UNAVCO. Unfortunatley due to the paucity of cGPS stations in the region of the earthquake (there are only about 20 other cGPS stations in Oklahoma), there are no measurements of the pre earthquake or co-seismic deformation as there were no cGPS stations sufficiently nearby. The 8 station network was designed to capture any post-seismic deformation generated by the earthquake and the previous fluid disposal. After the earthquake a number of injection wells were closed, and the earhtquake activity in the area has begun to subside.

Crustal deformation studies using cGPS need ~3 years before they provide a reliable, useable position time series, and we are reaching that time now. The data are being processed, but modeling has not yet begun. We will begin reporting on the results at upcoming meetings such as the fall 2019 American Geophysical Union meeting. All the data are collected daily and are openly available from the UNAVCO GPS data archive.

Another goal of the project was to start a GPS geodesy program at OU and OGS. CERI has been involved in GPS geodesy for over 25 years and, togehter with UNAVCO, trained collaborators from OU and OGS how to select sites, and install, operate and maintain the stations. OU and OGS have plans to expand the network in regions with teconic or induced earhtquake concerns. The equipment from UNAVCO has been replaced by new equipment acquried by OU and OGS and they are continuing to O&M the and send data to the UNAVCO archive.

This project was developed in response to the earthquake under the NSF Rapid program, which focuses on supporting data collection of efemeral data after significant geophysical events. Funding for RAPID projects is for 1 year, and we received two no-cost extensions, for a total of 3 years. While we do not have results just yet, the project was successful in that it has developed a team of earth scientists and funding sources in Oklahoma to continue collecting and analyzing crustal deformation data there for scientific and natural and induced earthquake hazard studies. The analysis phase is just starting based on the length of the time series becoming long enough to be reliable..
